summary: When they meet in second grade, Juli Baker falls instantly in love with her neighbor, Bryce Loski. Bryce, however, does not feel the spark. From that day forward, he (Callan McAuliffe) tries hard to keep brash and unpredictable Juli (Madeline Carroll) at bay. After six years, she begins to feel that she was wrong about him being the love of her life. Unfortunately, that is just about the time that Bryce begins to think he was wrong about Juli, too.

reviews.content: I'm watching this in 2023 and for no other reason this movie should be watched for medicinal purposes solely.
Kept me interested enough to watch until the end…. Just! But very disappointed
Contains many life lessons founded on time-tested principles.

It brings me nostalgia with my first crush.
I stumbled on this movie while browsing through Netflix, and only decided to watch because it was a Rob Reiner film.

I have to say that this was a wonderful film and definitely filed under "rewatch again in the future". If you've ever been in love for the first time, this movie will bring back a lot of those feels. I also loved the 50's setting that brought a nice "Wonder Years" vibe to the film.

Anyone who gave this movie a 1 star rating is probably a "flat" person and has the same deep down emotional turmoil and prejudice as Bryce's dad. For everyone else,

This movie is the cutest most feel good movie ever. I loved everything about it, from start to finish. So sweet and just overall pleasant. Both main stars were tremendous, they really meshed well together.
good small story,i loved the direction but there was a bit too much dialogue/voice over for me, but still worth the watch.
Very cute story even though Bryce made me really angry sometimes it's the type of movie to watch in a boring Sunday

Absolutely beautiful, heartfelt, with greatly written characters & a healthy, relatable romance story between two young teenagers without the over the top drama. This movie does a great job of diving deep into the different points of views, perspectives, actions & thoughts towards certain situations that 2 kids growing up would tangle themselves in. Very Highly recommend to watch & read the Book it's based on.
Filme incrível. Todo seu enredo, a forma como e contada, escolhas de uma narrativa vista dos dois ângulos cada um com uma perspectiva diferente de um sentimento desconhecido. simplesmente sublime...

loved it! Heart warming story we've all been there. Lots of relatable parts of growing up learning about love and friendship...and that it doesn't always start or end the way you think it does. I loved every minute of this coming of age tale!

Sweet and innocent, although without any real effort on character development. It is plain and simple actually, Bryce eventually allows himself to see the obvious, that the girl next door, however whimsical, is actually a remarkable and hard-working person, a fact rather obvious to the audience's eyes and in fact not even annoying any more. The main problem of the film is the obviousness of the just how unfounded his prejudice against her really is, which results in his realization being rather mild and sparkless...

Flipped is a movie that released on 2010 directed by Rob Reiner. I really love the movie because the amazing plot. This movie really surprised me even with the cliché romance trope of being in love with someone, hating them, and then eventually falling back in love with them, the movie captured young love perfectly.Like when she was head over heels for him, he didn't want her but the moment she stop giving him attention he starts chasing her.

It's always nice to watch a movie I'd not heard of and have it be so charming. Beautifully directed, nicely acted.  The musical background was almost too busy, but became irrelevant as the film progressed. I wish it had gone on longer.
People in 2010 were dumb when they rated this movie low. When I saw it on Netflix it was amazing.
Great coming of age movie for two kids and there families.

This movie really surprised me even with the cliché romance trope of being in love with someone, hating them, and then eventually falling back in love with them, the movie captured young love perfectly. Not to mention the representation of the 60's era was really captivating.

I thought this was really good for the most part. There were some times that I felt like the movie was taking a bit to develop. I think that might be related to the dual stories going on throughout the movie, but in the end it was really a decent movie.

I liked it very much. Realistic dialogue. Good memories of childhood. Didn't like seeing Anthony Edwards in an unsympathetic role. Would have maybe liked to see his back story resolved some. It was really him that was the catalyst for Bryce's cowardly behavior.

I stumbled on this movie while browsing through Netflix, and only decided to watch because it was a Rob Reiner film. 

I have to say that this was a wonderful film and definitely filed under "rewatch again in the future". If you've ever been in love for the first time, this movie will bring back a lot of those feels. I also loved the 50's setting that brought a nice "Wonder Years" vibe to the film. 

Anyone who gave this movie a 1 star rating is probably a "flat" person and has the same deep down emotional turmoil and prejudice as Bryce's dad. For everyone else, this movie will not disappoint.
A refreshing romantic movie

It took me 11 years to find this romantic gem. Right off the bat I would warn you if you can't stand stories about puppy love you may want to skip this since it involves a couple of 7th graders, but this is one of the sweetest and most wholesome love stories I have seen in a while. Of course the main storyline involves a person who can't stand the wonderful girl who is in love with him until he realizes he has feelings for her...its a common theme but the fantastic performances by the film's two leads help make this a very watchable love story. It's not perfect and it can be slightly sappy at times but if you don't feel a warmth in your heart by the end, you may be without a romantic bone in your body. A great couple of performances by the late John Mahoney and Aidan Quinn add to the film's strong cast.

Horrible.   How can a person that is not a good human even have a shot with someone that is clearly a more advanced being?   Without spoilers, the ending is a foregone conclusion and I found my temper rising throughout the movie.   One young person goes through a journey of life with thoughtful reflection and courage.  The other person learns lessons by screwing up repeatedly and ultimately learns a simple gesture of goodwill makes it all go away.  The movie teaches us nothing except that if you are cute you get more chances than the rest of society.    Is the movie cute?  Sure, but the lessons taught in it are dangerous for anyone to learn.   It's not about rescuing someone off of the trash heap to make them better, it's about making sure the heart wants someone on the same level.   I only wished I watched a movie that was on that level.  This is the biggest disappointment for me in Rob Reiner's universe and just may have "flipped" my opinion about watching anything he does.  Save yourself the heartache and skip this one.
While the movie convinced me that there was depth to the main female character, I failed to understand why she would pursue such a vacuous main male character.
Loved it. Very human, and sweet.
heart-warming movie, make you realized how pure love is.
This shouldn't even be compared to Stand by me because that's not even a romantic film and while the theme is nothing new at least the tone is strong

I need to reread the book since it's been a while, but I felt like the movie was missing something important from the book its based on. I can't remember what, but the film was super slow, and then suddenly it was over. I remember the story arc of the book being much more exciting.
adorable, light, fun.

I have no idea why critics rated this so harshly. This is hands down, one of the best romantic movies I have ever seen - so wholesome, so funny, so cute and the characters had so much depth and development. Absolutely love this movie and have seen it a dozen times.
Beautiful love story, another gem in Reiners' filmography

Warning!! Spoiler ahead!!
In the movie Flipped, it talks about first love and growth. When the Loski family moves to a new neighbourhood, Juli Baker falls in love with Bryce Loski at first sight. Bryce Loski is a boy who grows up in a family with a lot of rules. What he needs to do and what he shouldn't are all under his parents' control. Juli Baker is a girl full of energy and grows up in a family with love, even though they are not rich- they don't have nice furniture and the yard is full of weeds. Her favourite thing is climbing up an old sycamore tree and sitting there to see the scenery. But because of the construction, the tree needs to be cut down. She defends it to the death, with hoping that her friend Bryce will fight side by side, but he hesitates. They are in the same class, and Juli always tries to get closer to Bryce, but he avoids it. At school, Juli wins the first place in the science and technology exhibition for her chicken-laying project and becomes the focus of the audience, which eclipses Bryce. She gives Bryce the eggs from the hens she raised, but he secretly throws them away when Mrs. Loski suspects that her eggs were unhygienic because the hens are being raised in the messy yard. She is very sad when she sees him do that, and the relationship between the two falls to a freezing point. Juli starts to think maybe he is not worth it, and tries to ignore him at school. She argues with her parents, why they couldn't have a big house with a nice garden so others won't think her eggs are unhygienic. It turns out Juli's father has a disabled brother. Mr. Baker and Mrs. Baker needs to take care of him and keep him happy. That's why they don't have many things left for themselves and are often hard up for money. Now Juli understands and is willing to make changes. She starts weeding herself and planting flowers in the yard. Finally, Bryce realizes he should be braver and brings a sycamore sapling for Juli. 
The theme in this movie is family love and never judging someone or something you don't really know. How Juli and Bryce view things differently are mainly due to their families. Juli's dad teaches her to fight for the thing that she cares about. So Juli climbs up the tree to prevent the constructors from cutting it down. Even though Bryce wants to help Juli, he doesn't have the courage to stand with her and protect the tree because he doesn't want to get trouble. After the tree has been cut down, Bryce doesn't say anything to comfort Juli or apologize for it. As Juli cries in her bed, her dad shows her the painting of the tree and tells her when the treasured things are not there anymore physically we can still remember it in another way. 
People often look down on others' success and think it just happens by chance. However, the true reason is they can't do it, or have failed before. That applies to Bryce; he feels shocked and upset when Juli did hatch the chicks because she makes the impossible thing possible. When the Loskis family talks about the Bakers, they are mean and rude to judge Juli's uncle with cruel words. This particularly shows we shouldn't be prejudged if we do not walk in the same shoes that they do. 
I like how the sycamore tree is thought out in the movie. At the beginning, it is presented as Juli's favorite place which shows how Juli is unique from other girls. After the tree has been cut, the tree becomes a painting by her father that hangs in her room. This time, the tree is a symbol of the love in the family, that we are always here to support each other. Then at the ending sense, Bryce brings a sycamore sapling to Juli and they plant it together. The sycamore tree is the witness of the children's pure hearts. I highly recommend this movie as it reminds me when we are young we should chase after the things we are passionate about. We are allowed to make mistakes, when we are just getting to know this world, but the important thing is to learn from it and prevent it from happening again. As we learn more from the past, we will meet better versions of ourselves.
Really enjoy this movie, and I fliped.
Es una muy buena película que cualquier  persona puede ver sin complicaciones, muy recomendable.
It 's like seeing the beauty of the tree for the first time, like seeing your shiny eyes for the first time
Excellent narrative and good performances by the kids.

I thought it was amazing very appropriate, I love how it shows both perspectives, events take place in 1957–1963 in the screenplay instead like in the book of late 20's century which is why I enjoyed it even more, I love how they express their thoughts so pure, old school love, making it very unique among how movies are commonly centered around, drugs, sex, but this one proved my standards on why movies like these deserve more recognition which is why I enjoyed it, the only thing is I wished the author would've done is a sequel to the book, *spoiler alert* I would've loved to know what happens after the sycamore tree grows if Bryce Loski and Julie Baker end up dating in High School, or grow old together like Bryce's grandpa Chet and his grandma.

Critics have called Flipped, "A true gem", & "an instant classic", so I have to ask, what were they smoking when they watched this movie? The story follows Bryce Loski (Callan McAuliffe) who has just moved to a new neighborhood with his family. Before he's even gone into the house his new neighbor, Juli Baker (Madeline Carroll) has come over to say hi, and for her it's love at first sight. Bryce, being all of eight years old, finds Juli annoying, but that doesn't stop her from stalking him all the way to high school. Will Bryce always find her annoying or will he eventually feel the same way about her? Well, I think the title of the film is a huge spoiler in and of itself, but that's besides the point. The entire film follows their interactions together, first told from his point of view, and then again from her point of view, making the whole thing very repetitive. The film offers nothing else besides the interactions of these two kids, no side stories, no friends, and even limited family interactions, it's literally just one meeting between Bryce and Juli after another. This is a film by Rob Reiner, the Director of Stand By Me, The Princess Bride, Spinal Tap, and countless other great films! I realize that not everything is going to be a home run, but couldn't he see how boring this movie was? Flipped is slow, repetitive, and even the damn title is a spoiler. This is most definitely one you can skip.
a light-hearted movie showcasing the innocence of first love. also with a strong theme of family
The sweetest movie ever. Shows the first love story.

But when the film moves away from the romance and focuses more on the day to day life, the film comes into its own, so if you're like me and you can't stand most romantic films, then this film is just the ticket.

Opposites attract is one of filmmakers' favorite tropes. However, this opposition tends to be kept to relatively superficial, sometimes even external, traits.
The neurotic introvert and the fiery extrovert, the goody two shoes and the daredevil, the nerd and the most popular person in school, the list goes on and on.
A trope with tropes of its own. Us humans differ in much more fundamental ways than that though. Flipped inspects the different ways in which we love.
When protagonist Juli meets her new neighbor, Bryce, at seven years old something inside her flips and she falls in love. Her love for him becomes a part of herself that she can't separate from the rest of herself and his perfection a truth of the universe. Bryce spends years trying to avoid the crazy girl next door. He looks at her poor family, her pushy and stubborn nature and sees nothing inside her that would make her deserving of his attention. Here lies their most fundamental difference Bryce's love must be earned, whereas Juli loves just becomes. And at no point during the movie are we told that either of them is wrong. Sure, Bryce can be a bit of an unfeeling jerk, and perhaps somewhat of a coward, and Juli comes of as incredibly naive, but the writers mock neither. And they don't change. Bryce may widen his definition of the word worthy and Juli may realize that loving someone does not make them perfect, but the way they love does not change. It just becomes more nuanced. 
The dual perspective only intensifies this. The actors are perfect for their parts and give spectacular performances, especially given that they are actual children in stead of twenty year olds. It is definitely a must see movie.

Rob Reiner delivers another nostalgia fest of a film, a movie that seemingly has no qualms with sickingly saccharine moments of youthful innocence.

Does Flipped compare to other similar Reiner films, like Stand By Me? No.

But what Flipped does, it does well. The acting is genuine, and manages to capture a semblance of the timeless facets of youth that seem unburdened by time. Although the film can err on playing out like something out of a 50's TV series, Reiner manages to blend the cutesy kitsch with touching moments that keep this film from turning into a sugary mess.

One could argue the film is slow and uneventful, and to a certain extant I agree. Despite this, Flipped manages to intrigue and make you feel all fuzzy inside. 3.5/5.

this movie was BAD and needed to take a REST and decide who it wanted to be. the worst thing i have ever seen in the whole of my life, an hour and a half of my life that would have been better spent literally stabbing myself in the eyes, i will never get that time back.

This film was incredibly sweet, if not too cutesy at times. The incredible innocence was captured very well by the lead actors; it was believable in how ridiculous the thought process played out for either of them (in terms of youthful innocence).The acting itself was alright, which makes sense given how young either lead was, and I felt Anthony Edwards did a generally poor job as the prickly Mr. Loski.

Flipped utilizes its very talented cast and double-narrative story idea on a nostalgic, poignant and dramatic love tale between two contrasting personalities, providing enough drama and heart to keep one intrigued.
This film is just like a stream of water that can purify one's mind. After the bombardment of scifi, thriller, love story blockbuster, this film serve as a reset bottom to reset our mind.

Reviews from students in the after-school film club at the New York Tibetan Service Center:

DB: "Flipped" was very interesting in the way that the director chose to narrate the movie.  It was nice to know both sides of the story, both Bryce's and Julie's thoughts.  In addition, it was cool how they combined an average middle- schooler's life with an exciting love story.

Jewel: I thought that Bryce and Julie should have just kept a distance from each other!  I do not really think Bryce's dad should have treated the Baker family wrongly.  He was a judgmental hypocrite.

Danbo: The movie "Flipped" is a good  movie.  It is wonderful how they show both points of view of the main characters, Julie and Bryce.  Although some things are not explained, such as why Bryce's dad hated music, it was overall a satisfying movie.  I like how the time of the movie was depicted, and it is a story that anyone can relate to.

ABSOLUTELY LOVE THIS MOVIE. very very cleverly done. Apart from the lack of talent from the actors playing the father of bryce and the disabled brother I really enjoyed this movie and it brought a tear to my eye. Definitely my sort of thing.

Flipped is a sweet, charming, moving, lovely, well-acted coming-of-age romantic drama comedy film.

While the plot offers nothing new in particular (as with mostly all rom-com films)...the 'girl meets boy' mixed with 'the not-your-typical girl next door' story, but the storytelling is slightly different. 
Adapted from the book with the same name by Wendelin Van Draanen, the film is presented in a rather unique 'he-said she-said' style, through the eyes and thoughts of the male lead, Bryce and then again through the eyes and thoughts of female lead, Juli, alternately presenting their views and perspectives on a shared set of events. 

Nearly every single event that happened in the film is told at least twice, although it seems repetitive, but surprisingly, it never feels boring or annoying. It's actually fascinating and insightful to be able to see into the thoughts and feelings of people in general. Things are not really what it seems and there's always more than meets the eye. As the film progresses, you are so emotionally invested in the characters that you actually begin to eagerly anticipate what the other side of the story might be, how the other person feels the way he/she does. 

The film also gives a feeling of nostalgia, even for those who never lived in the era (the story is set in 50's or 60's suburban area) or experienced the same events as the two leads. It feels authentic and relatable nonetheless. Juli might appear as an ordinary girl, but she's a sweet, kind, beautiful, daring girl at heart once you get to know her.

The two lead stars are perfect in their respective roles. Most of the characters in the film have sufficient character development for the audience to understand them. Flipped is a period young love story, told in a simple and heartfelt manner. A rare cinematic gem.

Rating: 8/10


"A painting is more than the sum of its parts. A cow by itself is just a cow. A meadow by itself is just grass, flowers. And the sun peeking through the trees is just a beam of light.But if you put them all together...it can be magic.You have to look at the whole landscape to see its beauty."

"Some of us get dipped in flat, some in satin, some in gloss; but every once in a while, you find someone who's iridescent, and once you do, nothing will ever compare."

I love the romance that Juliana and Bryce are having together

This film had potential at its start. But the story failed to uphold any notion of a decent, satisfying plot.  The writers tried to make the movie "real". But when does any real-life situation even come close to a nonexistent possibility like this? The character development was, put bluntly, lame.  The cinematography wasn't bad, I will give them that, but overall this movie was a waste of 35 mm and time.
Flipped is surprisingly a decent watch.

Surprisingly engaging. Both leads are great. The device of showing events from both perspectives is well used. My only real issue is that some of the language seems a bit modern, given the period setting.
Charmingly made movie.. It taught us about life, what's important and most valuable, also to stand on what you believe. I love Juli Baker character, as a teenager she's really mature ^^

This is one of those films that gets into your mind and heart. It's a cute movie it's  always like this, girl meets a boy and falls in love with him but he doesn't likes her until he lose her for real. Young Julie is beautiful she kinds give you a lesson of love, what you want in life or what you believe in. So for this being a cute little film about young kid love, I give "Flipped" a solid C.
I've never seen a movie so drawn out. it's sad to see a movie with such potential be ruined.

The perfect movie about first love.

My advice: don't watch this. It's totally plotless, stupid, and overrated. Go watch something better than this. I couldn't even make it to the halfway point. Plus, even kids, the film's target audience, won't enjoy it. Setting it in the 1960s doesn't help. Even though I'm not easily offended by language, there's a lot of swearing for a so-called "kids" movie.

Flipped looks great. Too bad its not. The story could have been great but they try to express too much in the plainest of terms. They tried to write a smart script but instead it was bland and unexciting. The story of Flipped was like butter spread too thinly on a thick piece of bread.

It was a really cute movie :) I think it's better than Romeo & Juliet because Romeo & Juliet happens within 3 days & they end up committing suicide when they hardly know each other & flipped they get to know each other & when they fight they don't do something stupid :)

Rob Reiner is a dude who made actual movies, movies with an interest in being engaging and unique and entertaining. Spinal Tap was a groundbreaking mockumentary. Princess Bride helped turn the fantasy genre on its head. When Harry Met Sally and Stand By Me were incredibly personal and relatable. Few Good Men is fast-paced and wonderfully written. Flipped, on the other hand, is nothing but an emotional trainwreck that takes a unique structure conceit and goes nowhere with it.
Depicts how young love is and what young people face during that time.  I love it . So innocent and charming.
